swift/container/sharder.py.message:
this updates the status_changed_at but not the put/delete timestamps, so the *first* shard replica to have been updated from a root becomes dominant when the shards replicate to each other (i.e. the oldest status_changed_at wins in replication)

i.e. during replication, shards may well undo any useful policy update from root

eventually, once roots become sync'd, shards will converge on the root policy, but there could be ping ponging along the way.

test/unit/container/test_sharder.py.message:
this is only true because the test creates the shard brokers with (likely) older put timestamp than the the roots, which means the shards only pay attention to a recreated root.

In the more likely case that shards have newer put timestamps, they will update to whatever the root sends them, which results in shard policies ping-ponging until the roots sync to a single policy.

deployment/podman/podman-baremetal-ansib.message:
Just FTR, 'container_registry_insecure_registries' is not the parent key here.

It's the (enclosing) 'key' for a 'value' which is decided based on a condition. If you don't have 'else', there is no value to use when the condition is false. Hence the key is ignored and it's a 'feature'.

I think the condition here was incorrect to start with, if we expect to use whatever is there in the parameter (which already has a default). I just changed it mechanically assuming that there would be defaults for this var in ansible roles and tasks, which was not the case.

If we expect ansible vars would not have defaults, we can probably check where else conditions are used in 'set_fact' and change those (if touched by the simplification changes).

heat intrinsic 'if' without 'else' has number of benefits.

- Allows us remove tasks/resource properties etc altogether based on a conditions.
- Reduces the unnecessary empty defaults and the issues when you use them in other intrinsic functions
- Finally reduces the template size and readability

There is no issue here as is. We handle this var very badly in the tripleo_podman role.

We set a default for this var in https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/defaults/main.yml#L23

And then again create another var from it in https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/defaults/main.yml#L36

Ansible does not use the L23 when doing L36.

Weird that we use so many different vars unnecessarily in the role. But changing L36 as below (like other vars there) and removing L23 should fix it.

tripleo_podman_insecure_registries: "{{ tripleo_container_registry_insecure_registries | default([] }}"

But I'm fine if we want to merge this.

L23 in that role is a different var. Notice the "tripleo_" prefix there. That *will* get used at L36. Afacit, the var set here "container_registry_insecure_registries" is only used here in this template in the "Run podman install" task below.

Maybe the actual bug is that this var is spelled wrong, and should be prefixed with "tripleo_"? In fact, all these vars need to be prefixed with tripleo_ afaict

So we don't actually want/need the whole instance object here. We simply need the UUID. '_local_delete_cleanup' is only calling placement with the UUID and it calls '_update_queued_for_deletion' which gets an 'InstanceMapping' by instance UUID ('InstanceMapping.get_by_instance_uuid'). The logging handler can also handle being called with 'instance_uuid' instead of 'instance' (can't find the code for that rn but it's around somewhere and there are existing examples in e.g. 'nova/scheduler/utils.py').

Could we just store the UUID instead? I'd be okay with doing this in a follow-up to ease backporting but it seems...less hacky (?) than saving a dirty copy of an object when the underlying DB record has been deleted

I superficially considered that but wasn't sure about the logging handler thing and I also thought to myself, "what if someone wanted to expand _local_delete_cleanup in the future?" and didn't look deeper into it, but maybe I was overthinking it. Let me take a look at it again because I agree it would feel less odd and more targeted to pass only instance_uuid.

Note to reviewers: here is where instance_uuid is handled for the '[instance: <uuid>]' log formatting:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.log/blob/3.36.0/oslo_log/formatters.py#L409

an simpler alternative would be to store the instance as old_instance before we try to look it up again. If the look up produces None then we can use the old instance in _local_delete_cleanup()

                old_instance = instance
                cell, instance = self._lookup_instance(context, instance.uuid)
                if not instance:
                    # Instance is already deleted
                    self._local_delete_cleanup(context, old_instance)

   part2dev = array.array('H', gz_file.read(part2dev_len))

I think we need to start documenting the (unzipped) format somewhat like you'd see in an RFC. So currently, we've got v1's unzipped format looking something like

 +---------------+-------+---------------+------------...---+
 |'R' '1' 'N' 'G'| 00 01 | <JSON length> | <JSON text ... > |
 +---------------+-------+---------------+------------...---+

followed by N replica tables that look like

 +-------+-------+--...--+-------+
 | <dev> | <dev> |  ...  | <dev> |
 +-------+-------+--...--+-------+

where the last table may be truncated to accommodate fractional replicas.

It sounds like Clay's in favor of redefining the replica tables to be more like

 +---------------+-------+-------+--...--+-------+
 |  <table len>  | <dev> | <dev> |  ...  | <dev> |
 +---------------+-------+-------+--...--+-------+

where each table is prefixed by a length in bytes, similar to the <JSON length> above.

Matt is justifiably concerned that our theoretical maximum part power is 32, leading to 2**32 entries in the replica table, whose length overflows a 32-bit int *even with one byte device ids*! While we'd never recommend that anyone have a part power that large (*especially* while we're still limited to 16-bit device ids!), we can't rely on it always being lower, so we need to account for it somehow. Going up to a 64-bit <table len> seems reasonable. I'd avoid trying to have it smaller -- getting off 2/4/8-byte ints seems like a fairly serious maintenance burden and the stream is going to get gzip'ed anyway. I'll be glad when we can drop py2 and start using !Q instead of !II and manually combining. I'd vote against doing much bit-packing for similar maintainability reasons.

Since the first N-1 tables should all be the same length, I wonder if it'd be worth doing something more like

 +-------------------------------+----------...---+-...-+----------...---+
 | <total length of all tables>  | <table 1 ... > | ... | <table N ... > |
 +-------------------------------+----------...---+-...-+----------...---+

where each replica's table is defined similar to how we have it now. That total length should still fit quite comfortably in 64 bits.

---

I also wonder if it'd be good to throw a type byte in front of our length-value pairs, so we get something like

 +---------------+-------+
 |'R' '1' 'N' 'G'| 00 02 |
 +---------------+-------+

 +---+---------------+------------...---+
 + 00+ <JSON length> | <JSON text ... > |
 +---+---------------+------------...---+

 +---+-------------------------------+-------------------...---+
 + 01+ <total length>                | <series of tables ... > |
 +---+-------------------------------+-------------------...---+

 +---+-------------------------------+---------------------...---+
 + 02+ <table length>                | <last primary table ... > |
 +---+-------------------------------+---------------------...---+

where, for example, we know upon seeing the 0 that (1) we've got a four-byte length to read and (2) it'll be some JSON ring metadata.

If we later add still-more data to the ring, it'd also allow us to drop the last-primary table if the ring's been balanced for a while but we still wanted to send out updated type-03 data.

---

As for the possibility of <JSON length> overflowing 32 bits, it looks like each dev in my saio adds ~170 bytes to the JSON metadata -- let's round it up to 200 to accommodate IPv6 (and for rounder numbers). Leaving some space for non-devs metadata, let's say we've got ~4B bytes to play with -- so we'd expect to be able to handle ~20M devices. I think we'll need to rethink a lot of things before we get close to that limit.

OTOH, I could see an argument that it'd be nice to standardize on 64-bit lengths so we can continue parsing in the face of unrecognized types. Though presumably we'd want to order data in the ring by type code, so encountering an unknown type would be an indication that you can just halt parsing since there's nothing left you understand.

No doubt there probably already is some module for this somewhere, but the code seems pretty straight forward, if we want to pack over 2 4-byte values because of the py33+ 8 byte limitation: https://paste.opendev.org/show/808192/

I'm a little curius about this. doing some quick maths, 'I' representing UINT of 4 bytes (as you denote there). If we want to allow for a max size of a part2dev would be 2^32 (32 partpower, which is crazy) but that's already a 4 byte number.
If we then do for each dev_id being currently 2 bytes (not even taking into account Tim's change for this to possibly become 4 bytes) means the potentual number of bytes we need to store for a single part2dev:

  In [3]: 2 ** 32 * 2
  Out[3]: 8589934592

At 4 bytes a dev_id:

  In [4]: 2 ** 32 * 4
  Out[4]: 17179869184

Both of which we'll need 5 bytes to store these numbers into. So maybe we'd need to store 8 bytes per counter. So the ring will grow 8 * replica count (+1 when we add the last_part table) bytes in version 2.
But Tim mentions here (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/761794/4/swift/common/ring/utils.py) that 'Q' or 8 bytes is only available in py33+ which could be a problem. So I guess I could have a play with packing them into multiple smaller units, like over 2 4 byte units.

If we continue that thought, if dev_ids potentually becoming 4 bytes each, I wonder if there is a chance that json_len would start being too small, and should we think about space for future growth here too.

Just food for thought while thinking about v2 serialization.

Been thinking about this some more.. and thought of a way to really be able to properly scale to any number but only use a minimum of 5bytes and only use more as required.

If we're always going to use 4 byte chunks for a len, then no matter how big it goes we only ever need to track the bitshift of the last bytes (the rest will be 32). We can store that in 5 bits. Therefore we'd have 3 bits of the first byte (if we only use one byte) to indicate the number of 4byte blocks (so max of 8 blocks [or maybe 7, but 0 can mean 1 right]).
This means we could have a theoredical max of (8 * 4 * 8 bits) 2^256 count (that's a big number).. but only even using storing a minimum of 5 bytes (1 for the bitwise and count + 4 bytes for the first block). And we can just add 4 byte blocks/uints as we grow.

I think this packs down really nicely.

Fair concern -- looks like Python's using doubles, so 52-bit mantissa. Floats would be a real pain -- their 23-bit mantissa would have us already running into trouble.

Playing with something crazy like 48 replicas:

 >>> 48.0 + 1./2**46
 48.000000000000014
 >>> 48.0 + 1./2**47
 48.00000000000001
 >>> 48.0 + 1./2**48
 48.0

Yeah, seems like this ought to be exact for a full part-power-32 ring (assuming a not-insane replica count). It even round-trips well through JSON:

it's like the attribute replica_count that we write down in .ring.gz is totally divorced from the attribute .replica_count on the hydrated Ring instance
yeah it totally is, it's just the len of the replica2part2dev_id structure, so in essence a ceil(ring.replica_count).

The more I read of what get_replica_legths is used for. its for calulating what the lengths of a replica2part2dev_id should be. In deserialise_v1 it's used to figure out how big the arrays are to read out of the file, and in RingBuilder._adjust_replica2part2dev_size when we rebalance and we either need to create the inital or adjust based on replica count changes. From there the Ring/Ringdata.replica_count is based off the replica2part2dev_id atructure, or in the case of Ringbuilder.replica_count it's the count passed in.

So I guess we could build a ring, then take it's parts and replica count, run it though this function and see if the lengths match. Clay: FWIW, I remember doing a patch a while ago involving write_builder (so, taking a ring and doing what we can to recreate the builder) and thinking about this a decent bit -- I eventually decided I was OK with the builder having a replica_count that doesn't match the replica2part2dev table to make sure that any already-written tooling for replica increase would be guaranteed to make progress. A loop like

 while rb.replica_count < 4:
     rb.replica_count += 0.01
     # write ring
     # push ring out
     # wait for replication

turns into an infinite loop if

 rb.replica_count += 0.01

may leave replica_count unchanged. Just some food for thought.

Matt: I'm not opposed to using ring code to write something out, then modify the .ring.gz to suit the test. It may be challenging to truncate and still have a valid gz, but validating that we get some kind of IOError seems like a good idea. For *too much* data, we should be able to just append another gz stream:

 $ echo foo | gzip > foo.gz
 $ echo bar | gzip > bar.gz
 $ cat foo.gz bar.gz | gunzip
 foo
 bar

The on-disk bytes will be a little different from what we'd get when we start writing last primaries, but not at a level that I think we're likely to care about

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/s.message:
I'm not sure how this fully addresses the issue. The function is invoked during multiple operations, and handling the exception this way essentially prevents the higher layers from knowing something went wrong. Consider the volume creation flow: it will have no idea there's a problem, and will proceed to completion, and may actually overwrite the volume status again.

I think you need to consider handling this exception at a higher layer.

I don't know much about cinder's replication feature, but there's a replication_status field that would seem to be better suited than setting the volume status.

Your response doesn't address the points I raised. I know what the code is doing (logging the failure and setting the volume status). That is not in question. My point is the upper layers of code have no knowledge that something failed, and operations like creating a volume will proceed as if everything is fine. That doesn't seem like a good approach.

You state, "this issue is observed mainly during bulk operations." Have you considered adding retry logic to the part of the code? Other drivers do that. The goal is to prevent a soft failure (often a timeout due to something being temporarily overloaded) into a hard failure (volume in ERROR state).

In the current exception handling,
1. We display the error log saying that it failed to fetch relationship details.
2. We update the metadata for volume 'status' as ERROR. With this user will know why and where the operation is failed. 

This issue is observed mainly during bulk operations on volume, sometimes get_relationship_info command failed on the storage, so the volume metadata is not updated properly and we leave the volume is in an 'available' state. Users will never know that volume metadata is partially updated or not updated properly.

Handling this exception for 'get_relationship_info' as it is the only backend call from the function '_update_replication_properties' by forcefully updating the volume status as 'error'.

OK, as per [1] we don't need a new API microversion for this.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#f2

The microversion code is for upgrading scenario: while there is compute node stay older version, we reject the smartnic request, until upgrading finished. I hope you talk the same "API microversion" as I do.

I talk about the fact that you introduced a new response code to the API. In general that would require a API microversion bump. But for 400 it does not need a new microversion as per our doc:

"The exception to not needing a microversion when returning a previously unspecified error code is the 400, 403, 404 and 415 cases. This is considered OK to return even if previously unspecified in the code since it’s implied given keystone authentication can fail with a 403 and API validation can fail with a 400 for invalid json request body. Request to url/resource that does not exist always fails with 404. Invalid content types are handled before API methods are called which results in a 415." [1]

This is not enough for installing ansible lint, you must also install ansible and yamllint to have a workable setup.

Which version of ansible is up to you as it works with base version or the full ACD, as long is >=2.9.
 
Please check https://ansible-lint.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installing.html#using-pip-or-pipx
How would you install ansible-lint for this job?
I would use `pip3 install "ansible-lint[community,yamllint]"` from the docs. It installs the full-ansible and yamllint.

community does install the "fat" ansible and it may fail to spot problems for users that do not expect to use full ansible version.

If we are to create a role for running linter we should give the user the option to override that and pick a different version of ansible he wants to test against.

There is another problem with this approach: it will break badly on systems that already have another version of ansible installed. As you know ansible, ansible-base and ansible-core packages cannot be upgraded between 2.9,2.10 and 2.11.

That is why installing ansible-lint is safe only inside a virtualenv, so we not risk conflicting with system ansible.

Not sure to understand, are you suggesting we replace the `pip install --user` with:

One main issue i encountered while testing this is:

If a snapshot is in available state and snapshot support is disabled then also user can delete the 'available' snapshot which IMO shouldn't be allowed (and the purpose of this check here).

I think we only need to allow deletion of snapshots which are in 'error' state when snapshot support is disabled (if the purpose of patch is to cleanup failed snapshots)

Also my suggestion : the best case would be to cleanup the created snapshot before raising exception at L#555 and L#564 during 'create' operation while snapshot support is disabled

I disagree. If snapshots were created, then the decision was made to disable snapshots, we should still allow those available snapshots to be deleted. Otherwise there is no way to get rid of them without reconfiguring the system.

Nit: method bodies like this, which delegate entirely to their superclass, should be avoided. These two exceptions can be defined by simply replacing their bodies with `pass`:

class UnknownBugTypeException(Exception):
    pass

That would work just fine and have the same net effect.
Done

Nit: using mutable objects as default argument values in Python can lead to some surprising behaviour. In this case you're immune from it, but given that you never use the default value anyway you should consider moving to a more idiomatic pattern.

Changing to an idiomatic pattern would also make it possible to initialise the BugTrackerManager with no bug trackers in it, which is currently impossible in this model (because empty lists are falsy).

The idiom would be to have `bug_trackers=None`, and then change the line below to `bug_trackers = bug_trackers if bug_trackers is not None else [LaunchpadBugTracker()]`. I appreciate the line is longer, but it's a fair bit more explicit.
Fixed. Wouldn't the next line be equivalent as-is?

This leads to some surprising behaviour. Specifically, this happens:

>>> first_manager = BugTrackerManager(bug_trackers=[LaunchpadBugTracker()])
>>> second_manager = BugTrackerManager(bug_trackers=[JiraBugTracker()])
>>> first_manager.bug_trackers is second_manager.bug_trackers
True

Essentially, you have here a class that references a singleton bug tracker dictionary. That means that each time you create a new bug tracker manager, it automatically gets the bug trackers each other manager has, and also updates all those other bug trackers.

I suspect this is not what you actually intended. To avoid it, remove the class-scope declaration of bug_trackers and instead begin the __init__ method with `self.bug_trackers = {}`. That will give each manager its own unique bug tracker dictionary. Alternatively, if it *is* intended, you should really comment this to explain why it's a desired behaviour.

That was not intended. I didn't realize those (outside of __init__) were class scoped variables. I thought they were equivalent. I'll have to revisit that in other code I wrote. Thanks.

Fixed.

Is there any reason the bug type should be mutable, or different for different instances of the same class? Put another way, is there any value in having this?

>>> x = LaunchpadBugTracker()
>>> y = LaunchpadBugTracker(config={'bug_type': 'foobar'})

If there isn't, having this config dict is really overkill, and you should simply have a class-scoped variable that each subclass overrides called `bug_type`.

The reason for this is because the bug-type could come from the config file.  See the last few lines of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/375113/19/elastic_recheck/config.py

I fixed it by making it a required param. I think this simplifies quite a bit.
If you move away from using the config dict, this entire method can simply be removed and you can just call `tracker.bug_type` directly.
Done

Nit: insert standard warning against parsing structured data types using regular expressions. A URL parser would be a better tool for this. However, don't let the perfect be the enemy of the good: so long as this works, I'm happy enough for you to keep using the regex approach. It can always be improved later.
Yeah, we can do this later. In fact, I hope there can be some bug tracker specific library that can do even better at parsing its own urls.

The reason I suggested changing this was in case users did something like this:

BugTrackerManager(bug_trackers=[])

In this instance, the user might expect that this would create a bug tracker manager with no bug trackers, but that's not what happens: instead, they get a bug tracker manager with a launchpad bug tracker. In fact, the user has to leap through some pretty major hoops to create an empty bug tracker manager.

That may be a deliberate part of your design, but it's definitely a weird wart to my eyes. I'd want either a comment explaining that this is deliberate or the change, I think.

Because the ceph-admin user is only created for mons,mgrs,osds for deployed_ceph I should still run this for the other groups during non-deployed ceph.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/797539/4..6/deployment/cephadm/ceph-base.yaml

If you used deployed_ceph, then at this stage of the deployment enable_ceph_admin_user.yml has already run and created the ceph-admin user on all nodes in the groups ceph_mon, ceph_mgr, and ceph_osd. Thus, we don't want to re-run enable_ceph_admin_user.yml unless we're now going to configure the rgw, mds, nfs, or rbdmirror service AND those services are not collocated with the monitor. Only in that case should we re-run it and it will run on the additional nodes in that group. In that case, enable_ceph_admin_user.yml will be run again on all ceph related groups in the overcloud but it is idempotent.

Is it not a problem for the user to have their image metadata requesting multiqueue be silently ignored? That is, they make a mistake and put a flavor with 1 VCPU and want multiqueue and they get an instance that does not have multiqueue. Scenario: they had meant to choose a flavor with 2 VCPU to use with the image that requests multiqueue but because of their mistake they now have an instance with 1 VCPU and no multiqueue.

I'm wondering, why is it better to do this than to reject this combination at the API layer and return a 400 (fail fast)?

I partially agree with melwitt's suggestion from an API and dev PoV, but the user's PoV is different IMO. In one of my customer's cloud (more specifically the one that hit this issue), the use case is that users don't really need to care about what images have multiqueue enabled or not. It is desirable that all images have multiqueue so it provides the best performance, but the user experience is bad when they select 1 vcpu flavor and it crashes, so the cloud provider would have to provide duplicate images without the multiqueue only for 1 vcpu flavor. It adds a bit of confusion to the user of why there are special images just for 1 vcpu usage.

Thanks both for explaining, I see now why it makes sense to omit the "multiqueue" when there is only one queue. A user requesting one queue per VCPU will actually get what they requested with this change.

no i dont think so.

the contract for multi queue is that you get one queue per guest cpu.
so wehn you have 1 cpu you should only have 1 queue.

also for some reason we are not aware of this seams to only affect vif_type=tap as gibi confrim
that multi queue with a singel vcpu works in other cases.

ack but we need to figure if the "stable" version we want to use in tripleo/ci should then be -testing or -release

Please do not use cbs.c.o Koji generated repos directly, they are rebuilt on every build-tag so it might regen while the job is running leading to repodata mismatch.

You can use NODEPOOL_BUILDLOGS_CENTOS_PROXY instead:
baseurl: ${NODEPOOL_BUILDLOGS_CENTOS_PROXY}/centos/7/storage/x86_64/ceph-luminous/

NB drawback is that you need to wait for periodic buildlogs sync, which can be up to 4h after tagging in -testing tag but it also gives you proxy-caching, also repodata in buildlogs keep few versions back, so sync mid-job will not break it.

BTW for multiarch, we need to start using $basearch instead of explicit x86_64 but that's OT here...

actions/list_inconsistent_objs.py.message: this should probably be `inconsistent_objects` or just `objects` since its within context.

Dumping json output is useful for machine driven actions, but we need to consider the output format for humans as well. As such, we should have a --format yaml option that enables the yaml output, but put out a more friendly human output in the message.
This action should have a format argument as well, and default to a human readable format
Yep. I've now added said argument, which defaults to pretty JSON.
If the format is not a valid format we should treat it as an error. Therefore, you should probably check the format is valid before running the operation to list the inconsistent objects
Sounds right. Do you think it's acceptable to default to any format if it wasn't specified, or should we make the format parameter mandatory ?

Yaml vs json still isn't really "human readable" output. While it may be pretty json, its still machine formatted output. This should be something like `<inconsistent_obj_name> (pg)` or `[pg] <inconsistent_obj_name>` and output as a list.

In the scale up section of the cephadm docs [1] we say:

"An updated Ceph spec will be generated and installed on the bootstrap node, i.e. /home/ceph-admin/specs/ceph_spec.yaml on the bootstrap node will contain new entries for the new CephStorage nodes."

Because of line 37 above and line 109 below, this won't always be true.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/797538/12/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_run_cephadm/tasks/prepare.yml

We will need to update the documentation to state that it is only the case if you're not using deployed_ceph. Then in the case of deployed ceph, the scenario gets re-written so that after you add the node you re-run "openstack overcloud ceph provision" so that it can generate the new spec and apply it for scale up.

So the above changes are deliberate and we should update the documentation accordingly IMO.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/cephadm.html#scenario-scale-up-ceph-with-tripleo-and-metalsmith

wdyt

The values of the following variables will always be overridden if the supported interfaces are used (deployed_ceph or THT). 

tripleo_cephadm_container_ns
tripleo_cephadm_container_image
tripleo_cephadm_container_tag

I only switched them from docker.io to quay.io and from Octopus to Pacific (v15 to v16) because they are more modern for W and X. I could also just leave them blank by setting them all to "".

Whether you use deployed_ceph or not these values will use what is in:

 /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-common/container-images/container_image_prepare_defaults.yaml

The deployed_ceph command line options give you additional ways to override them if desired:

  --container-image-prepare CONTAINER_IMAGE_PREPARE
                        Path to an alternative
                        container_image_prepare_defaults.yaml. Used to control
                        which Ceph container is pulled by cephadm via the
                        ceph_namespace, ceph_image, and ceph_tag variables in
                        addition to registry authentication via
                        ContainerImageRegistryCredentials.

container_group:
  The following options may be used to override the values set via
  --container-image-prepare-path. If the example variables below were set
  the image would be concatenated into quay.io/ceph/ceph:latest and a custom
  registry login would be used.

  --container-namespace CONTAINER_NAMESPACE
                        e.g. quay.io/ceph
  --container-image CONTAINER_IMAGE
                        e.g. ceph
  --container-tag CONTAINER_TAG
                        e.g. latest
  --registry-url REGISTRY_URL
  --registry-username REGISTRY_USERNAME
  --registry-password REGISTRY_PASSWORD

But they are just additional ways. The only way these defaults would be used is if someone ran the role without the supported interfaces (deployed_ceph or THT). In that case I wanted to have something that should work because we always use those variables:

The length of the command to be executed on the shell is finite. In a situation where there are a lot of nodes, then we might have a command that is too long to be correctly called and it will get truncated. If instead we put all of the nodes in a file, the file can be very large without growing the command length. since tripleo_cephadm_predeployed is only used in pre.yaml, I'm wondering if we can just remove this variable and use directly tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph to achieve the same result.
I know we have 3 use cases here:

1. deployed_ceph (before the overcloud): in this case tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is true, and the task in pre.yaml can be skipped (the when condition can be -> "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph")

2. ceph is deployed during the overcloud: in this case cephadm should be already present in the overcloud image, the task in pre.yaml is executed (because tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is false, hence not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph makes the task being executed), but since the pkg is already there, the task has no effect.

3. predeployed servers (e.g. centos w/o any ceph package): in this case, tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph: false, and having the condition defined as "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph" makes the task being executed, which is correct.

Can you review this theory and see if I'm overlooking at some details?

> since tripleo_cephadm_predeployed is only used in pre.yaml, 

Yes, right here:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/tasks/pre.yaml#L17-L23

> I'm wondering if we can just remove this variable and use directly tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph to achieve the same result.

Do you mean update line 23 above so tripleo_cephadm_predeployed doesn't exist and deployed_ceph is in its place? I was thinking that would break backwards compatibility. Might we break wallaby non-deployed_ceph scenarios which use predeployed servers by doing this? Maybe not.

> I know we have 3 use cases here:
> 1. deployed_ceph (before the overcloud): in this case tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is true, and the task in pre.yaml can be skipped (the when condition can be -> "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph")

Just to be clear I want pre.yml executed but not the task calling the package module.

> 2. ceph is deployed during the overcloud: in this case cephadm should be already present in the overcloud image, the task in pre.yaml is executed (because tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is false, hence not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph makes the task being executed), but since the pkg is already there, the task has no effect.

Note that in the deployed_ceph scenario the task can have an effect and it's not a good one; that's why I added this line to be sure it wouldn't get executed. IIRC, in my testing it tries to install the cephadm package but no repository configuration has been done yet so it fails for that reason (even though the package is there). Repository configuration happens during overcloud deployment so I don't want to call the package module before overcloud deployment. However, I know you're referring not to the deployed_ceph scenario but when the overcloud is configuring Ceph.

> 3. predeployed servers (e.g. centos w/o any ceph package): in this case, tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph: false, and having the condition defined as "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph" makes the task being executed, which is correct. 

I guess the predeployed server scenario (where metalsmith isn't used by something else is used) won't support deployed_ceph (at least for now).

So there's four possibilities:

1. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  0 0  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph
2. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  0 1  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph
3. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  1 0  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph
4. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  1 1  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph

Is there ever a case where scenario 2 or 3 are valid? I guess not. 

So are you proposing then that tripleo_cephadm_predeployed be replaced with tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph in the following?

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/tasks/pre.yaml#L23

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/defaults/main.yml#L44

I think that would be OK. Please confirm.

> > since tripleo_cephadm_predeployed is only used in pre.yaml, 
> 
> Yes, right here:
> 
> https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/tasks/pre.yaml#L17-L23
> 
> > I'm wondering if we can just remove this variable and use directly tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph to achieve the same result.
> 
> Do you mean update line 23 above so tripleo_cephadm_predeployed doesn't exist and deployed_ceph is in its place? I was thinking that would break backwards compatibility. Might we break wallaby non-deployed_ceph scenarios which use predeployed servers by doing this? Maybe not.

Yes, I was trying to avoid duplicated variables since the goal is the same at that point of the playbook (either have pre-deployed nodes or an already deployed ceph cluster).
However, I understand that preserving the backward compatibility for wallaby users is the first goal, hence I'm ok keeping the two variables.
My initial concern was about the "confusion" that could be generated seeing both deployed_ceph  and tripleo_cephadm_predeployed at the same time, but you can always drive the value of the latter using the deployed_ceph boolean.

> 
> > I know we have 3 use cases here:
> > 1. deployed_ceph (before the overcloud): in this case tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is true, and the task in pre.yaml can be skipped (the when condition can be -> "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph")
> 
> Just to be clear I want pre.yml executed but not the task calling the package module.

Exactly, and merging the two variables is just an optimization since  "tripleo_cephadm_predeployed" is only used in pre.yaml#L17-L23
> 
> > 2. ceph is deployed during the overcloud: in this case cephadm should be already present in the overcloud image, the task in pre.yaml is executed (because tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph is false, hence not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph makes the task being executed), but since the pkg is already there, the task has no effect.
> 
> Note that in the deployed_ceph scenario the task can have an effect and it's not a good one; that's why I added this line to be sure it wouldn't get executed. IIRC, in my testing it tries to install the cephadm package but no repository configuration has been done yet so it fails for that reason (even though the package is there). Repository configuration happens during overcloud deployment so I don't want to call the package module before overcloud deployment. However, I know you're referring not to the deployed_ceph scenario but when the overcloud is configuring Ceph.

ack I see, I thought the package was already there because the overcloud image has it, but I can be wrong, so +1 on skipping the task.
My argument was mostly on using only one variable (deployed_ceph) but as per the previous sections, maybe it's better to keep them separated.

> 
> > 3. predeployed servers (e.g. centos w/o any ceph package): in this case, tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph: false, and having the condition defined as "not tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph" makes the task being executed, which is correct.

> 2. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  0 1  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph
> 3. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  1 0  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph
> 4. tripleo_cephadm_predeployed  1 1  tripleo_cephadm_deployed_ceph

Not sure, you can have pre-deployed nodes but keep deploying ceph **during** the overcloud deployment (which is scenario #3), or you couldn't have predeployed nodes but you can always choose to deploy Ceph during the overcloud deployment (which is scenario #2).
So I see all 4 valid possibilities, and this led to keep the two boolean separated, so we can override them according to the choosen scenario.

nova/compute/utils.py.message: I don't see how delete_arqs_by_uuid can raise AcceleratorRequestOpFailed

If there is both dp_name(from extra spec) and arq_uuids(from port), on failure case, delete_arqs_for_instance would delete all arqs belongs to a instance include the arqs belong ports. And then delete_arqs_by_uuid will find the arq is deleted already, and we cloud ignore this failure safely.

Continuing from PS10
> > I don't see how delete_arqs_by_uuid can raise AcceleratorRequestOpFailed
> If there is both dp_name(from extra spec) and arq_uuids(from port), on failure case, delete_arqs_for_instance would delete all arqs belongs to a instance include the arqs belong ports. And then delete_arqs_by_uuid will find the arq is deleted already, and we cloud ignore this failure safely.
When you try to delete an ARQ that was already deleted with cyclient.delete_arqs_by_uuid(arq_uuids) call then that call will not raise AcceleratorRequestOpFailed exception. It will just log warning. cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: Would this cleanup logic also need to be run pre-flatten?  Create a snapshot, clone from snapshot, delete snapshot (results in new .deleted meta-image), clone the snapshot volume into new volume, flatten parent due to chain length, delete the snapshot volume -- at this point, the volume no longer knows about it's original parent.

Wait, I think I'm wrong about that.

So, in the RBD driver there are two cases where a parent/child relationship is broken:

1. On create volume from snapshot, if flatten_from_snapshot is set, then the volume will be flattened.  This isn't an issue because the snapshot must already exist, and the flattening will cause a later snapshot delete to skip pending stuff.

2. When max_clone_depth is reached.  This logic is only invoked for volume_from_volume, which I believe cannot effect the pending snapshot logic.  It doesn't walk backup up the chain, it just checks if the limit is reached and then issues copy() instead of clone().

I /think/ we're okay.
Do we need a "finally" sentence here? As if any exception is raised, we still need to do volume/snapshot close().
Is it possible to create two volumes from the same snapshot?  If so, it could raise an ImageBusy exception here when deleting the first clone.
That case should be caught in _get_pending_snapshot() which will only return a snapshot object if there are no other dependencies.
Because I didn't know you could do that ;)
Is it not possible to have more elements in this list? If yes, what is supposed to happen if len(children) == 2, for example?
I see what you're saying, readability here is terrible.  I can do better.
Could we have a logging here to make sure this code works during CI at least? Since bug 1648885 happens randomly, we need to have explicit evidence that this patch helps.
I'm sorry for my mistake. The judgement has been made here whether the placeholer exist or not.
I am convinced by your consummate solution. IMO,while the snapshot only have "1 children" && "have been asked to deleted"(have a placeholder with its id), then it will be removed.

This isn't the full story. The scheduler can automatically translate a number of image metadata properties, including 'hw_video_model', into traits. This functionality is enabled via '[scheduler] image_metadata_prefilter' and its implementation can be seen in 'transform_image_metadata' in 'nova/scheduler/request_filter.py'. We need this because the libvirt driver will report this trait if libvirt itself says it supports it (via domain capabilities - see '_get_video_model_traits' in 'nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver'). Without the libvirt driver reporting this trait, the scheduler won't find a host to support this.

So, tl;dr: we need this to allows the scheduler to find hosts with support for this video model when the image metadata scheduler prefilter is enabled (via '[scheduler] image_metadata_prefilter').

ansible/roles/cloudkitty/tasks/bootstrap.message:
Not idempotent - fails on the second run with a 400. I ended up with this:


+- name: Checking if Cloudkitty elasticsearch index exists
+  become: true
+  kolla_toolbox:
+    module_name: uri
+    module_args:
+      url: "{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_url }}/{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_index_name }}"
+      status_code: 200, 404
+  run_once: true
+  delegate_to: "{{ groups['cloudkitty-api'][0] }}"
+  register: cloudkitty_index
+  when: cloudkitty_storage_backend == 'elasticsearch'
+
+- name: Creating Cloudkitty elasticsearch index
+  become: true
+  kolla_toolbox:
+    module_name: uri
+    module_args:
+      url: "{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_url }}/{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_index_name }}"
+      method: PUT
+      return_content: yes
+      body: |
+        {}
+      body_format: json
+  run_once: True
+  delegate_to: "{{ groups['cloudkitty-api'][0] }}"
+  when:
+    - cloudkitty_storage_backend == 'elasticsearch'
+    - cloudkitty_index.get('status') != 200
+

I ended up with the following code:

- name: Checking if Cloudkitty elasticsearch index exists
  become: true
  kolla_toolbox:
    module_name: uri 
    module_args:
      url: "{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_url }}/{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_index_name }}"
      status_code: 200, 404 
  run_once: true
  delegate_to: "{{ groups['cloudkitty-api'][0] }}"
  register: cloudkitty_index
  when: cloudkitty_storage_backend == 'elasticsearch'

- name: Creating Cloudkitty elasticsearch index
  become: true
  kolla_toolbox:
    module_name: uri 
    module_args:
      url: "{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_url }}/{{ cloudkitty_elasticsearch_index_name }}"
      method: PUT 
      return_content: yes 
      body: |
        {}
      body_format: json
  run_once: True
  delegate_to: "{{ groups['cloudkitty-api'][0] }}"
  when:
    - cloudkitty_storage_backend == 'elasticsearch'
    - cloudkitty_index.get('status') != 200

nova.network.neutron.API.create_resource_requests

nova.conductor.manager.ComputeTaskManager.build_instances
->
nova.conductor.manager.ComputeTaskManager._create_and_bind_arq_for_instance
